title: People and cities in MusicBo: Knowledge Graph Overview
subtitle: An insight into the MusicBo corpus discovering the people and cities mentioned through knowledge extraction.
curator: John Patrick Bulseco Nulud, Rita Gramellini, Elisa Mastrorilli
description: The MusicBo corpus consists of 135 texts that delve into the rich music heritage of Bologna. By exploring its knowledge graph, you can access data that offers both a quantitative and qualitative glimpse into the contents of the corpus. It's an innovative way to get a deeper understanding of the fascinating musical world of Bologna. Get ready for this amazing journey!

dynamic_elements.text: Let's start by taking a quick peek at the MusicBo corpus to see just how many people and cities are mentioned. This will give us a sense of the multitude of individuals and locations that contributed to Bologna's vibrant musical heritage.

dynamic_elements.count_query:
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX amr: <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/>
 
SELECT distinct (count(distinct ?s) as ?count) 
WHERE {?s rdf:type <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/Person>. 
}

PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX amr: <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/>
 
SELECT distinct (count(distinct ?s) as ?count) 
WHERE {?s rdf:type amr:City.
}

dynamic_elements.text: Check out this map to discover which cities are specifically mentioned in the MusicBo corpus!

dynamic_elements.map_title: Location of the cities mentioned in MusicBo
dynamic_elements.map_points_query:
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX owl: <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#>
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX wdt: <http://www.wikidata.org/prop/direct/>
PREFIX wikibase: <http://wikiba.se/ontology#>
PREFIX p: <http://www.wikidata.org/prop/>
PREFIX wd: <http://www.wikidata.org/entity/>
PREFIX ps: <http://www.wikidata.org/prop/statement/>
PREFIX psv: <http://www.wikidata.org/prop/statement/value/>
PREFIX wdr: <http://www.w3.org/2007/05/powder#>
PREFIX amr: <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/>

SELECT DISTINCT ?point ?label ?frameInstance ?lat ?long

WHERE { 

  ?cityUri rdf:type amr:City ; 
    owl:sameAs ?point ; 
    amr:name ?label .

  FILTER (regex(str(?point), "http://www.wikidata.org/entity/", "i"))

  ?frameInstance ?p ?cityUri ; 
    rdf:type ?frame . 
SERVICE <https://query.wikidata.org/bigdata/namespace/wdq/sparql> 
  { ?point wdt:P31/wdt:P279* wd:Q515 . 
    ?point p:P625 ?coords_stmt . 
    ?coords_stmt ps:P625 ?coords;
      psv:P625 [ wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat; wikibase:geoLongitude ?long ] . 

  }
  }

dynamic_elements.text:
Did you notice that the cities are highly concentrated in Europe?

This can be also attributed to the Grand Tour, started in the XVIII century. This significant phenomenon allowed musicians, composers, and also music enthusiasts to visit prominent cities, like Bologna, and initiate a cultural exchange that involved the entire Europe. As a matter of fact, the Grand Tour had a profound impact on the dissemination of Bologna's music heritage across the continent.

dynamic_elements.chart_title: Top 10 most cited cities in MusicBo
dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX amr: <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/>
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>

 
SELECT DISTINCT ?label (COUNT(distinct ?s) as ?count)
WHERE 
{?s rdf:type amr:City ; 
amr:name ?label  .
}

GROUP BY ?label ?count 
ORDER BY DESC(?count)
LIMIT 10

dynamic_elements.text: As we continue our journey of MusicBo's discovery, there's one question we need to ask: who are the top 10 people that appear the most in the corpus?

dynamic_elements.chart_title: Top 10 most cited people in MusicBo
dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX amr: <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/>

SELECT distinct ?label (COUNT(distinct ?s) as ?count)
WHERE {?s rdf:type <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/Person>. 
    ?s <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/name> ?label  .
}
 
GROUP BY ?label ?count 
ORDER BY DESC(?count)
LIMIT 10

dynamic_elements.text:
And the prize for the most cited person in the MusicBo corpus goes to... Gioacchino Rossini!

Such an important person deserves a worthy introduction. Get ready to discover some biographical information, his notable works, and the cities that embraced his talent. But that's not all: you'll also see an image of this extraordinary musical genius!

dynamic_elements.chart_title: Cities where Rossini left his mark

dynamic_elements.text:
Many are the cities that embraced Rossini’s talent and were influenced by his musical genius.  

But why is Rossini so popular? The MusicBo corpus reveals some reasons behind his fame: 

Music in the Present Tense Rossini Italian's Operas in Their Time, Emanuele Senici (2019)

The music of Rossini is universally appreciated for no other reason than because his melodies are either entirely popular, and lifted, so to speak, from the mouths of the people; or resemble those successions of tones which the people are generally familiar with and have become accustomed to, that is, popular.

At times it seems almost as if Rossini is some sort of 1950s rock ’n’ roll star, out to corrupt young, impressionable, and, yes, mostly female minds with his “physical” music.

Carpani goes on to list the myriad forms in which Rossini’s music spread throughout Italy and the many different nonoperatic situations in which it featured: military marches, Tafelmusik, church organs, orchestral accompaniment to theatrical dance, the tavern, the street, the salon, pianos, and so on: “We still haven’t heard this music only from church bells or repeated by the plumed inhabitants of wood trees.

Numerous people like him contributed to enriching Bologna's music scene and spreading its heritage all over the world. Do you want to know if a person played an important role in Bologna's music tradition?
